title: The Government's Prevent database doesn't keep us safe, it's control
text:
The Government is operating a secret database of every referral ever made to the anti-radicalisation programme, Prevent (Picture: Alberto Pezzali/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

The human rights group, Liberty, has just revealed that the Government is operating a secret database of every referral ever made to the anti-radicalisation programme, Prevent.

We uncovered this database through freedom of information requests – and what we found is disturbing for a number of reasons.

Firstly, it was built by the police and contains information that is stored and shared without people’s knowledge or consent, which disproves the Government’s recent claim that Prevent is a safeguarding policy.

Many of those on the database haven’t actually done anything wrong – they are reported to Prevent because of what they’re perceived to think or believe. In fact, less than one out of 10 referrals to Prevent have resulted in deradicalisation action.

Every police force can add people to the database, and the Home Office is able to access the information it holds. We don’t know how long the information is held or whether other Government departments or outside organisations – like the NHS or local authorities – can access it.

Advertisement

This database isn’t about keeping us safe. It’s about keeping tabs on and controlling people, particularly minority communities and political activists.

We don’t know exactly how many people this affects, but we do know that in 2017-2018 alone there were 7,318 referrals. Over half of those people were under 20 years old, and one third of referrals were made by the education sector.

The majority of information on the database is gathered by public servants who have been co-opted by the Home Office under Prevent and encouraged to view even very young children as potential future criminals. Four years ago, a mum arrived at her sons’ primary school to be told her boys were being held in the library, awaiting police questioning. The majority of information on the database is gathered by public servants who have been co-opted by the Home Office under Prevent and encouraged to view even very young children as potential future criminals. The boys had told a teacher who had received training for Prevent that they had toy guns and the school had called the police to alert them to that the children were at risk of radicalisation. After legal action by Liberty on the children’s behalf, the local education authority admitted the boys had been discriminated against and their human rights had been breached. Later, the school also raised other ‘concerns’; one of the children said he had been to a mosque when he hadn’t and that he speaks Arabic, even though he doesn’t. Worryingly, the teachers failed to understand that even if this was true, these are not signs of radicalisation. The way the system forces teachers – as well as nurses, doctors and other public servants – to report purported signs of so-called extremism destroys the trust that should underscore relationships like those between teachers and pupils. It forces teachers to be suspicious, and leaves pupils and their families afraid to speak openly. Along with the Domestic Extremism Database, Gangs Matrix and the massive migrant database, Prevent is just the latest example of the Government’s increasingly totalitarian approach to policing. Ministers and the police must do the right thing and tell people if they are on this database, what information is stored and how this is or will be used. Only then can the Government and police truly be held accountable for what they do with it. Without transparency, it’s near impossible to challenge what’s on the database. More: Home Office 'Racist' Home Office passport system couldn't recognise black man's lips Body scanners at London station can see if people are carrying knives Nigerian who lost passport deliberately gets himself jailed so he can be deported The upcoming review of the system is a chance to give this damaging strategy the robust independent scrutiny it desperately needs – but the Government has hamstrung it before it’s even started. Any review which fails to examine the problematic premise that Prevent was founded on – or how it’s worked in the past – can only fail. It’s essential that the option to scrap Prevent and start again is kept on the table. As the first step to show they are serious about getting this review right, Ministers must rethink their appointment of a biased reviewer. Lord Carlile, who is undertaking the review, not only gave Prevent the green light in the first place but has been recorded saying ‘may be somewhat biased’ towards it. The communities worst affected by Prevent hope for this review to provide the robust, independent scrutiny it desperately needs – only a truly independent reviewer can deliver that. The Prevent strategy stifles speech, spreads fear and distrust, and encourages discrimination. It will continue to ruin lives until the Government takes action. description: The human rights group Liberty explains why the British Government needs to be held accountable for storing private details without consent.
